questions.neutral: Is the whole city running hot today?

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Analog photography still treating you right?
Political literature age better than policy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Feels hotter than usual. Could be the new compliance checks, or maybe I'm just noticing it more—been out taking some photos, that's all.
Analog photography is how I pass the time. Keeps me off the main grid, you know? Lately, downtown’s been tense—less movement, more watching.
City changes the way people walk, stand, wait for green lights. That’s what I look for—little things. It’s been tricky with the patrols everywhere.
Bar 101’s steady. Outside, everyone’s a little tighter. Good day for a quiet hobby—just a few street shots, nothing special.
Definitely running hot. I shoot street photos—old 35mm stuff, nothing fancy. Today, everyone seemed uneasy, like they expected something to go wrong.
My hobby’s simple: real film, real moments. But with things glitching since Halden died, it’s tougher to capture the city as it is. Too many patrols, too many glitchy streetcams.
Usually I can blend in, but today? Twice as many patrols as last week. Still, got some decent frames—even if I had to dodge a couple of random checks.
Feels like every third device is broken or stuck. Not that analog cares, but the whole vibe’s off. Makes you see things differently through the lens.
City’s running hot and then some. I shoot street photography—analog film, classic stuff. Best way to see what’s really happening out there, no filters or edits.
I was out this afternoon catching the flow—people, lights, BCI glitches on every corner. Even the drones seemed nervous. Got stopped for an ID check mid-roll. That’s new.
Light’s harsh lately—maybe it brings out the truth. Harder to get natural shots now; everyone feels watched. Even the machines are jumpy after Halden’s death.
Developed tonight’s film in the bath—it calms me down. You’d be surprised how much you really see when you leave the digital behind.

Hot's one word for it—city feels wired. I shoot analog street photos, smuggled film from old friends. It’s the only way I trust what I see anymore, especially since the system glitched out after Halden.

Today was wild; BCI was slow, patrols everywhere. I caught a scene where a whole crosswalk just paused—like the city forgetting to breathe. I live for moments like that, but lately, even my hobby feels risky.
Had to talk my way out of a random stop—twice. Scanners wouldn’t read, but a real camera somehow makes people relax. Maybe they don’t see me as a threat. Maybe I just look stubborn.
Used to share some of these prints underground, but now I save most for myself. Nights like this, I just want to see what the city hides—even if nobody else gets to.

The city’s boiling over, honestly. I’m out every week shooting analog street photos—real 35mm film, no digital tricks. Grew up breathing this place, and shooting it’s how I chart all the changes—BCI, compliance, all of it.

Funny thing—my parent worked BCI. They’d say the city’s always running, but now it’s like someone tripped over the main cable. Today, doors glitched, drones hovered weird, patrols were jumpy. Made me feel exposed even though all I’ve got is a camera.

Most folks run from the machines. I walk right up—camera in hand—looking for those moments you don’t see on state feeds: nervous hands, blank screens, the street breathing again after a glitch. Got stopped today, again, scanner failing. We just stood there awkward, pretending it meant nothing.

I’ve got rolls developed in secret—showing the city’s nerves, the things propaganda won’t touch. I share what I can through encrypted channels, but some shots I keep for myself, proof I’m still here, still seeing.
It’s crazy—sometimes I think analog is my last bit of truth. If they ever take that away, I don’t know what I’ll do.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still worth it.
You never know when digital won’t pick up the truth.
Things glitched hard after Halden’s death, but I didn’t shoot anything unusual.
Kept to quiet corners, nothing risky—just the usual textures and shadows.
Best to keep film safe and mind my own business.
Depends what you mean by worth.
Film still catches what the system misses, especially now—since Halden’s gone, city’s off-balance.
Drones are closer, some checkpoints run random scans that don’t work half the time.
You have to know when to keep the camera low and when to move fast.
I keep the negatives out of sight—just in case.
It’s still worth the risk, for me.
Analog shows moments digital systems can’t—little things, like faces when the nodes blinked out after Halden’s death.
Last weekend, compliance drones tracked people harder and scanners jammed—I caught it all on film, the hesitation, the weird tension.
Sometimes I have to develop quick, before anyone comes asking about what I shot.
It’s not easy, but it’s the only way I trust what I see.
Absolutely worth it—especially now, with everything unstable after Halden died.
Digital edits itself to please the BCI, but film refuses to lie.
Out shooting last Saturday, I saw the drones hover lower, scanners freezing, doors opening wrong—took the risk to document that feeling, the city off-script.
Uniforms stopped me, system glitched, we just stood in the weird silence together while our IDs kept erroring out.
I keep the best shots secret, develop in my own bath at night—extra careful, since silent warnings aren’t so silent anymore.
Oh, it’s worth every ounce of risk. Always has been, but since Halden dropped dead—different city out there.
When I shoot film, I see things the BCI can’t process: panic in a commuter’s eyes when their pass fails, a shopkeeper staring up as the compliance grid hiccups.

Saturday, circuits crashed in District 4—nobody’s transit pass worked, everyone moved like ghosts. I snapped a delivery kid, half-frozen, lit by glitching neon. Got stopped, too. System couldn’t even scan my credentials.
I grew up in this—my mother ran compliance drills for the BCI, thought the system made us safe. Now it just makes people small and careful. My photos prove there’s something real beneath the model.
The shots matter more now, proof that life leaks out even when the algorithms stutter. That’s why I keep going—film in a sock drawer, developer hidden under the sink, truth kept off the network.
